body.p: A Swift object server is a node that runs the swift-object service (only) and used to store object data. It does not run the swift-proxy, swift-account or swift-container services.
This section describes the procedure to allocate Swift Object Server during the initial deployment of the system.
Once the system has been deployed, a different procedure is used to add additional Swift object servers. - <What is that procedure? can user do it in Beta2 ?>

This page contains the following topics:
Procedure to Allocate Swift Object Server
Creating Server Role for Swift Object Servers
Swift Network and Service Requirement

section.title: Procedure to Allocate Swift Object Server

body.p: Perform the following steps to allocate Swift Object Servers:

ul.li: Verify if the example input model already contains a suitable server role. The server roles are usually described in data/server_roles.yml file. If the server role is not described, you must add a suitable server role as described in Creating Server Role for Swift Object Servers. While adding a server role for the Swift object server, you will also allocate drives to store object data as described in Allocating Disk Drives.

Verify if the example input model has a resource group assigned to Swift object servers. The resource group are usually assigned in data/control_plane.yml file. If it is not assigned, you must add a suitable resource group as described in Creating an Object Sever Resource Group

Identity the physical servers and their IP address and other detailed information. Add the servers details in either of the following YAML file and verify the server-groups information:
data/baremetalConfig.yml If you use Cobbler, add these details in the baremetal-servers list.
data/server.yml If you do not use Cobbler, add these details to servers list.
data/server_groups.yml Verify and/or modify the server-groups information with all servers.

body.p: The only part of this process that is unique to Swift is the allocation of disk drives for use by the object ring as described in Allocating Disk Drives for use by Swift.

section.title: Creating Server Role for Swift Object Servers

body.p: You must edit the data/server_roles.yml and add an entry to the server-roles list using the following syntax:server-roles: . . . - name: <pick-a-name> interface-model: <specify-a-name> disk-model: <specify-a-name>

The server roles have the following fields:
name This is a name assigned for the role. In the following example ROLE_SWPAC is the role name.
interface-model You can either select an existing interface model or create one specifically for Swift object servers. In the following example INTERFACE_SET_SWOBJ is used. See Swift Network and service Requirements more information.
disk-model You can either select an existing model or create one specifically for Swift object servers. In the following example DISK_SET_SWPAC and DISK_SET_SWOBJ is used (depending on context). See Allocating Disk Drives for more information.

example.codeblock: server-roles: . . . - name: ROLE-SWPAC interface-model: INTERFACE_SET_SWOBJ disk-model: DISK_SET_SWOBJ

section.title: Swift Network and Service Requirement
section.p: This section describes the network configuration for Swift. The network model allows many options and configurations. For smooth Swift to operation, the following must be true:

ul.li:
The following services must have a direct connection to the same network:
swift-proxy
swift-account
swift-container
swift-object
swift-ring-builder
The swift-proxy service must have a direct connection to the same network as the cluster-ip service.
The swift-proxy and memcached service must be co-located in the same cluster of the control plane.
The swift-proxy and switf-ring-builder service must be co-located in the same cluster of the control plane.
The ntp-client service must be present on all Swift nodes.
